pages.name: Part A

elements.name: Part A Info 1
elements.html:
All questions in this survey relate to your organisation’s operations in WA, inclusive of surrounding Commonwealth waters, subsidiaries and your share of joint ventures. Most of this survey can be completed on a group basis, except for the (a) COVID-19 workforce arrangement survey and (b) economic contributions survey.

Please note all responses are anonymised through aggregation. There will be no identifiable attributions.

elements.name: PartAQ1
elements.title: Select your organisation name

elements.name: PartAQ2
elements.title: What is your name?

elements.name: PartAQ3
elements.title: What is your position title in your organisation?

elements.name: PartAQ4
elements.title: What is your contact number?

elements.name: PartAQ5
elements.title: What is your email address?

pages.title: Part A: Organisation and representative details

elements.name: Part B Section 1
Part B Info 1
elements.html: Questions in this section are on workplace health and safety. We recommend assigning this section to your COVID-19 response, crisis management or business resilience teams to complete. Please read these questions carefully as a few ask about disruptions and impacts felt back in March 2020, rather than currently (July/August 2020).

elements.name: PartBQ1
elements.title: When WA had its first COVID-19 case back in March 2020, how prepared was your organisation to handle the disruptions it caused here in WA?

elements.name: PartBQ2
elements.title: Back in March 2020, to what extent was your organisation prepared to manage the health risks associated with the spread of infectious conditions?

choices.text: No infectious conditions identified in existing management plans
Limited types of infectious conditions identified in existing management plans (but not specific to COVID-19 risks)
Infectious conditions identified in existing management plans (already specific to COVID-19 risks)

elements.name: PartBQ3
elements.title: Back in March 2020, did you have an Employee Assistance Program (EAP)?

elements.name: PartBQ4
elements.title: Back in March 2020, to what extent did you provide these mental health and wellbeing support services?

choices.text: EAP available to both employees and their families
On top of the EAP being available to both employees and their families, various internal company measures in place

elements.name: PartBQ5
elements.title: Because of COVID-19 now, has your organisation introduced new or tailored existing measures to include more support for employee mental health and wellbeing?
elements.description: e.g. organisation wide measures to address broader concerns on work-related stress or fatigue, exposure to psychosocial hazards and risk factors.

elements.name: PartBQ6
elements.title: To what extent has a culture of safety and risk management provided a buffer to your organisation from the disruptions caused by COVID-19?
elements.description: e.g. your organisation’s experience with infectious conditions such as Zika and Ebola.

elements.name: PartBQ7
elements.title: Currently, how prepared is your organisation to handle a ‘second wave’ of infection in WA?
Section 1: Organisational preparedness and response

elements.name: Part B Section 2
Part B Info 2
elements.html: Remaining questions are on broader impacts to your organisation. We recommend assigning this section to a senior COVID-19 response coordinator or General Manager to complete.

elements.name: PartBQ8
elements.title: How much has COVID-19 affected the fundamental drivers of demand for your products?

elements.name: PartBQ9
elements.title: Overall, to what extent has your organisation been affected by COVID-19?

elements.name: PartBQ10
elements.title: How has COVID-19 affected your business?

rows.text: Loss of access to export markets
Cash flow or working capital difficulties

elements.name: PartBQ11
elements.title: Thinking back to the peak of travel restrictions (both inter- and intrastate during February and March 2020), how did it affect your business?

elements.name: PartBQ12
elements.title: Currently, how do travel restrictions enforced through the Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions affect your business?

elements.name: PartBQ13
elements.title: How has introduction of WA’s interstate hard border closure affected your business?

elements.name: PartBQ14
elements.title: If you operate in Commonwealth waters, how have travel restrictions enforced through the three nautical mile border affected your business?

elements.name: PartBQ15
elements.title: How has the closure of international borders affected your business?

elements.name: PartBQ16
elements.title: Has your organisation relocated skilled or experienced workers closer to operations (i.e. in response to borders closing)?

elements.name: PartBQ17
elements.title: Where were these skilled or experienced workers sourced from?

validators.text: Maximum value which can be entered for any one row item is 15,000
Maximum value which can be entered for any one row item is 15,000
Maximum value which can be entered for any one row item is 15,000

elements.name: PartBQ18
elements.title: How has your organisation approached the risk of disruptions to your supply chain? Please select all that apply.

elements.name: PartBQ19
elements.title: In response to COVID-19, what workforce management actions has your organisation taken? Please select all that apply.

choices.text: Cancellation of physical meetings (external and internal)
Designated essential and critical personnel, reducing levels of personnel onsite
Increased use of remote work and working from home
Updated leave policy (with or without pay)
Reduced hours or pay for employees
Mandatory return of Indigenous employees to community

elements.name: PartBQ20
elements.title: In response to COVID-19, what capital and financing actions has your organisation taken? Please select all that apply.

choices.text: Pause on exploration spending or other discretionary activities
Increased investment in technologies for automation, remote services or enabling working from home
Deferred capital expenditure or date of final investment decision
Deferred or scaled back non-critical maintenance
Salary and fee reductions of key senior management personnel and directors
Increased drawdown on credit and debt facilities

elements.name: PartBQ21
elements.title: In response to COVID-19, has your organisation undertaken any of these community support measures (inclusive of in-kind support)? Please select all that apply.
elements.description: Please note there is a separate question which asks for quantified contributions to community organisations.

choices.text: Directly supporting local communities or vulnerable groups
Increased support of local and small businesses, e.g. relaxing payment terms or grants with regional chambers of commerce
Made donations to organisations to help in COVID-19 prevention, management and recovery (i.e. not-for-profits)
Assisted in the transportation of medical equipment, samples and supplies
Assisted in the transportation of medical personnel and patients
Assisted in the transportation of perishables and food supplies
Assisted in the provision of accommodation

elements.title: Section 2: Disruptions and impact response

elements.name: Part B Section 3
PartBQ22
elements.title: How helpful has the State Government’s management of COVID-19 been for your business?

elements.name: PartBQ23
elements.title: Did you access the Commonwealth Government’s JobKeeper assistance program?

choices.text: Yes, we applied but were ineligible
No, we did not apply because of ineligibility
No, we did not seek to apply at all

elements.name: PartBQ24
elements.title: Should the State or Commonwealth Government provide some form of support to your organisation or sector?
elements.description: e.g. in encouraging recovery of the economy.

elements.name: PartBQ25
elements.title: How should the State or Commonwealth Government support your organisation or sector? Please select all that apply.

choices.text: Expanded criteria for accelerated depreciation on capital projects, (i.e. an ‘investment allowance’)
Royalty relief or other State-based tax relief
Expanded criteria or funding for the Exploration Incentive Scheme
Other State-based cost relief (e.g. discount on leases, port fees or energy inputs)
Direct training initiatives or wage incentives for apprentices and trainees
Reducing administrative burden of regulatory compliance
Streamline and reduce timeframe of approvals
Maintain certainty on free trade agreements and diplomatic relationships with Australia’s major trading partners (i.e. status quo on tariffs and foreign investment)

elements.title: Section 3: Role of Government

elements.name: Part B Section 4
PartBQ26
elements.title: What is your expectation your business will be operationally sustainable for the next six months? (to December 2020)

choices.text: Very confident it will become unsustainable

elements.name: PartBQ27
elements.title: What is your expectation your business will be operationally sustainable for the next 6 to 18 months? (January 2021 to December 2021)

choices.text: Very confident that it will improve
Very confident that it will worsen

elements.name: PartBQ28
elements.title: Because of restrictions imposed by COVID-19, are you now looking to resume deferred activities? e.g. a material backlog.

elements.name: PartBQ29
elements.title: Restrictions allowing, what deferred activities are immediate priorities to resume? (to December 2020) Please select all that apply.

choices.text: Ramping up operations to reach production capacity
Project development (i.e. progressing feasibility studies and final investment decisions)

elements.name: PartBQ30
elements.title: When WA’s hard border on interstate movements is lifted, how long do you expect it will take for your business to return to normal?
elements.description: i.e. revert to business as usual operations, pre-COVID-19.

elements.name: PartBQ31
elements.title: How do you see your expenditure with local suppliers changing over the next six to 18 months?

elements.name: PartBQ32
elements.title: Currently, which of the following best describes your organisation’s situation with skilled and experienced workers?

choices.text: Shortage affecting our ability to recruit for specific roles
We outsource and use external services

elements.name: PartBQ33
elements.title: In the next six months, which skilled and experienced positions are an immediate priority? (to December 2020)
elements.description: Please be specific with the position title, e.g. heavy-duty diesel mechanic or A-grade underground electrician.

validators.text: Entry must be more than six characters

elements.name: PartBQ34
elements.title: In the next six to 18 months, which skilled and experienced positions will be a priority? (January 2021 to December 2021)

validators.text: Entry must be longer than six characters

elements.name: PartBQ35
elements.title: To what extent would a recovery in the WA resources sector induce or stimulate recovery in other sectors of the WA economy?

elements.name: PartBQ36
elements.title: Which of the following factors has your organisation’s policies or view fundamentally changed by COVID-19?

choices.text: Workforce (including planning, workplace health and safety)

elements.name: PartBQ37
elements.title: Do you see your business substantially and permanently changing in fundamental ways from COVID-19?
Section 4: Future expectations

elements.title: Section 1: Corporate

elements.name: Part C Section 2
Part C Info 1
elements.html:
This section of the survey is aimed at understanding the full breadth of working hours and roster practices your organisation offers. This is being collected to assist in CME’s advocacy on the 2006 Code of Practice – Working Hours which is due for an imminent review. Through this process, it is expected there will be an increased prescription on length of rosters and working hours. To ensure the sector can maintain a risk-based approach, it will be critical to demonstrate the sector’s breadth and variability of these practices in providing flexibility to employees and in meeting operational needs.

As such, it is requested companies provide this information in way that appropriately shows this diversity. Please fill out this section of the survey based on project or type of operation. If you have similar rosters for multiple (a) projects or (b) operation types, you can combine.

templateElements.name: PartCQ10
templateElements.title: Will you provide roster information by project or type of operation?

choices.text: Types of operation – combining multiple projects across WA

•	Residential – Employees go home daily.</br>
•	DIDO – Employees stay onsite during the roster, then drive/bus/train home.</br>
•	FIFO – Employees get on an aircraft for any segment of their commute.

elements.name: Part E Info 1
elements.html:
Definitions here are those used by the Workplace Gender Equality Agency. Formal policies and strategies are written up and approved by management:

• Policy are guidelines, rules and procedures developed to govern actions and outline decision making. It is widely communicated and accessible by all employees.

• Strategies are action plans to achieve a vision, influencing the allocation and use of resources. It has executive approval, e.g. a Reconciliation Action Plan.

Informal policies and strategies may be undocumented processes or best practice intent of how the business should assess contracts.

elements.title: Do you have formal procurement policies or strategies relating to the following? Please select all that apply.

elements.name: Part F Info 1
elements.html:
The next four questions are about key enablers to maintaining/increase production.  The key enablers are:
</br>
People: Workforce, rostering, skilled employees
</br>
Energy: Electricity, gas, sourced or self-generation
</br>
Water: Supply
</br>
Infrastructure: Facilities, roads, rail, ports (air and sea), community infrastructure

Yes, issues relating to accessing private rail as third party
Yes, issues relating to accessing public rail
